title: A causal role for the prefrontal cortex in music-induced reward
synopsis: TMS + fMRI showed left dlPFC causally modulates music-induced pleasure and motivation; changes in nucleus accumbens activity and fronto-auditory connectivity explain differences in liking vs wanting.
appraisal: Strong causal evidence linking cortical control to subcortical reward circuitry; laboratory setting and short sessions limit direct clinical translation.
key_findings: dlPFC stimulation changed subjective pleasure and motivation
NAcc responses dissociated liking vs wanting
stat_methods: fMRI ROI and whole-brain analyses, mixed-effects models, PPI/connectivity analyses; multiple comparison corrections.
limitations: Moderate sample size, short sessions, localized TMS effects — limited ecological validity.
recommendations_for_artists: Produce recordings with emotionally salient moments
Create multiple edits (3-5 min, loopable segments)
Provide clear metadata and usage notes for clinical curators

title: Pleasurable music modulates reinforcement learning
synopsis: Pleasurable music biased reinforcement learning in a probabilistic selection task; effects depended on musical experience and listening style.
appraisal: Clear behavioral evidence linking music reward to learning processes; no direct neurochemical measures and limited ecological validity.
stat_methods: Probabilistic selection task analysis using repeated measures and mixed ANOVA; correlations with self-report pleasure.
limitations: Inferred mechanisms, short lab sessions; generalization to therapy contexts limited.
recommendations_for_artists: Create short cue tracks for reinforcement contexts (10-30s motifs)
Provide full and stripped versions to improve placement

title: Music interventions for preoperative anxiety (Cochrane Review)
synopsis: Meta-analysis of 26 randomized trials (~2,051 participants) found music listening reduced preoperative anxiety with a moderate effect size compared with standard care.
appraisal: Rigorous methodology and clinically relevant findings; heterogeneity across protocols and variable trial quality limit precision.
key_findings: Patient-centered choice and live music often stronger
stat_methods: Random-effects meta-analysis, SMD for anxiety outcomes, heterogeneity via I², sensitivity analyses by risk of bias.
limitations: Heterogeneity in timing, music types and outcomes; many small trials with unclear bias.
recommendations_for_artists: Create short calming playlists for digital delivery
Provide multiple file formats and licensing info for hospital integration

title: A brief music intervention reduces preoperative anxiety
synopsis: Randomized trial (n≈201) where a single 5-minute patient-preferred music session (live or recorded) lowered preoperative anxiety vs usual care; live music shortened immediate recovery time.
appraisal: Pragmatic design and clinically meaningful outcomes; short-term effect measurement and difficulty blinding are limitations.
key_findings: Live performances sometimes improved immediate recovery
stat_methods: Randomized design, between-group comparisons with t-tests/ANOVA and validated anxiety scales (e.g., STAI).
limitations: No long-term follow-up; potential expectancy effects; blinding is challenging.
recommendations_for_artists: Produce short 3–5 minute recordings optimized for calm
Provide stems and licensing to facilitate clinical use

title: Sensorimotor synchronization to music reduces pain
synopsis: Active synchronization (moving with music) produced larger reductions in perceived pain than passive listening or silence in experimental models, highlighting embodied engagement as an analgesic mechanism.
appraisal: Careful experimental design demonstrating an embodied effect; lab pain models may not fully represent chronic or palliative pain.
key_findings: Sensorimotor synchrony amplified pain reduction vs passive listening
stat_methods: Within-subject repeated measures ANOVA on pain ratings; contrasts across conditions with reported effect sizes.
limitations: Experimentally induced pain and short follow-up; careful translation required for clinical populations.
recommendations_for_artists: Provide 20–40s synchronizable segments with BPM markings
Deliver high-quality stems for app-driven movement programs
